conclusion: Analyze forces to find coefficients of friction (μ) and angle (θ).
The suitcase can be pushed or pulled on the ground.
Identify forces: weight (W), normal force (N), applied force (F), frictional force (f).
Weight of the suitcase W = 150 N.
Resolve applied force F into vertical (Fy) and horizontal (Fx) components.
Vertical component Fy = F sin θ.
Horizontal component Fx = F cos θ.
Net force in vertical and horizontal directions must be zero for uniform movement.
Vertical equilibrium: N + F sin θ = 150.
Horizontal equilibrium: F cos θ - f = 0.
Frictional force f is proportional to normal force N with coefficient μ.
Substitute f = μN into horizontal equilibrium: F cos θ = μN.
Substitute N from vertical equilibrium: N = 150 - F sin θ.
Substitute N into horizontal equation: F cos θ = μ(150 - F sin θ).
Given minimum pull F = 90 N.
Substitute F = 90 N: 90 cos θ = μ(60 - 90 sin θ).
Minimum pull occurs when vertical component balances weight minus normal force.
Substitute N back: 90 cos θ = μ(60 - 90 sin θ).
Solve for μ and θ: μ = 0.5, θ = 37°.
Final answer: μ = 0.5, θ = 37°.
